prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
(nearly identical to the technical justification of HIP27887)
We used our available Herschel data [5, 19] to predict the extent and surface brightness of the target assuming it is a debris disk. Therefore, we estimated the total flux of the disk at ALMA wavelengths from a blackbody fit (considering the spatial constraints from the images) to the relevant Herschel fluxes (larger than or equal to 100 micron). The use of a blackbody instead of a modified blackbody in the present case was well justified in [5] by the nature of the dust present (large, blackbody like grains instead of smaller grains). In the case of HIP92043 (another cold disk candidate not proposed here as it is predicted to be too faint for the proposed observations), an additional data point from a marginal detection with APEX/LABOCA at 870 micron is available [5]. This flux is consistent with - although by a factor of four higher than - the predicted flux from our blackbody fit (Fig. 1), which suggests that the actual flux of all candidates at ALMA wavelengths might be larger than predicted. In addition, we assumed the disks to be narrow rings with a radial extent smaller than the angular resolution of our proposed observations. This assumption is reasonable, since the disks must be very far from the star to be as cold as observed, but also close enough to be unresolved by Herschel/PACS at 160 micron, which leaves only a narrow range of radial distances from the star. Furthermore, the angular resolution of our proposed observations will be relatively low (band 6, most compact configuration, see below). Note that the extent of the cold disk (spatially unresolved by our Herschel observations at 160 micron and not detected at shorter wavelengths) is an upper limit which transforms into a lower limit of the surface brightness derived. Finally, we estimated the flux per beam by dividing the total flux by the number of beams needed to cover the whole circumference of the ring considering different wavelengths and array configurations ([5], also see [28] for a proof of concept). This gives a good lower limit (but probably close to the real value) of the flux per beam, which we require to be detected at 5 sigma confidence, sufficient to achieve our science goals.
We find band 6 and the most compact configuration to be ideal to achieve our goals in the shortest time possible due to the large beam surface covering a large region of the disk and thus accumulation more surface brightness per beam (interferometrically speaking, this results in observations at the lowest spatial frequencies, at which extended structures produce high coherent flux). Higher spatial resolution is not necessary for our science goals, as high spatial resolution studies of the disk are not the main goal of this project.
The largest angular scale of the source is set to the ring radius, while much smaller sub structures (e.g., the small radial width of the ring) are present ensuring that spatial filtering is not an issue (even the upper limit on the disk diameter is barely larger than the maximum resolvable scale). Thus, ACA is not required.
Fig. 2 shows a CASA simulation of the proposed observations on the example of HIP27887 based on our worst-case scenario (face-on disk, largest plausible extent, flux scaled to blackbody emission) to support our estimates and illustrate the quality of the expected observation.
Although gas is not expected to be present in disks of this age and low collisional excitation, its presence would reduce relative velocities and provide another explanation for the unusual size distribution observed. Thus, we optimize our observations for high sensitivity to continuum emission (no significant loss in sensitivity compared to pure continuum observations) but also allowing for the detection of possible CO in the disk.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
One of the most intriguing results of Herschel debris disk programs is the identification of a new class of cold disks incompatible with standard models. Micron-sized grains usually produced abundantly by collisions of larger bodies seem to be absent. This suggests disks of solids grown at the periphery of protoplanetary disks and now experiencing gentle collisions. They should comprise solids larger than millimeters, but smaller than a few kilometers in size to remain unstirred. This would imply that planetesimal accretion, at least in the outer regions of the systems, has stopped before cometary/asteroidal sizes were reached. Probing these disks promises invaluable new insights into planet formation processes. At the same time, given the limited angular resolution of Herschel, each single detection (but not all together) can also be explained by a background galaxy.
We propose to observe the three cold debris disk candidates accessible to ALMA. The high angular resolution data will allow us to clarify for each object whether it is a cold disk. Where confirmed, resolved images and millimeter fluxes in combination with our Herschel data will allow detailed investigation.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system
